video.title: Build a Website from Start to Finish using WordPress [Full Course]
video.description:
Learn how to build a completely custom website using WordPress, PHP, HTML, CSS, and Elementor. You will learn how set up your local server, create the design, and build a custom WordPress theme that works with Elementor. 

The design section is sped up because it is just an example about how the design is done. You can create your own design or use a preexisting design.

Once you have learned how to build out your website, you will learn how to get it from your local server to a production server and how to setup SEO, security, and caching the right way.

Don't worry if you don't know much PHP. Everything you need is explained in the course. 

💻 Assets (including mockup, theme folder, and images): https://github.com/thedevdrawer/sample-law-firm-template

✏️ This course was created by The Dev Drawer. Check out tutorials like this and many more
on his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCcr8eSk5xCfn3AbYy8WOWzg

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Intro
⌨️ (0:00:49) Designing Your Website (Speed Art)
⌨️ (0:03:03) Setting Up Your Local Server
⌨️ (0:04:50) Create Your WordPress Database
⌨️ (0:05:33) Download WordPress
⌨️ (0:06:26) Installing WordPress
⌨️ (0:08:07) Install Elementor and Theme Plugins
⌨️ (0:09:43) Creating Your Theme Files
⌨️ (0:11:57) Using functions.php to Set Up Your Theme Defaults
⌨️ (0:21:39) Creating Default Theme Pages
⌨️ (0:23:41) Install Your Theme
⌨️ (0:25:24) General Setup
⌨️ (0:32:05) Creating Header and Footer Blocks
⌨️ (1:01:25) Creating Your Home Page
⌨️ (1:35:18) Create Custom Post Type and Meta Boxes
⌨️ (1:42:02) Creating Shortcodes Using Your CPTs
⌨️ (2:16:10) Modifying Columns for Your CPTs
⌨️ (2:24:13) Create Your Menus
⌨️ (2:29:45) Creating Additional Pages
⌨️ (2:33:04) Create Single Pages for Your CPTs
⌨️ (2:51:25) Create A Form
⌨️ (3:03:16) Create Elementor Section Templates
⌨️ (3:20:00) Create Another CPT
⌨️ (4:27:18) Validate and Modify Mobile
⌨️ (4:34:50) Export Your Website for Production
⌨️ (4:46:12) Recommend Security, SEO, and Caching Plugins
⌨️ (4:48:10) Setup Security
⌨️ (4:56:25) Setup Caching
⌨️ (5:01:13) Setup SEO
⌨️ (5:08:51) Wrap Up

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Dev Drawer
topLevelComment.text: I hope you find this video interesting. It was a fun project and it is versatile, so you can take the core concepts and build on it to make a large variety of websites. Good luck.

replies.author: Okputu Okputu
replies.text: Thank you sensei

replies.author: Darrin Hubbard
replies.text: Not to be rude but you honestly shouldn't be making tutorials anymore. I dont think you know what the hell you are doing and I'm STILL stuck on how to do shortcodes. You can't seem to make up your mind as you go and you're going WAY too fast! 😤

replies.author: jakub gadzala
replies.text: The deeper I am in this video the more I realize how much I can do with it. Wordpress was so far a big clunky book to me after taking 2-3 fairly good courses on templates and plugins creation. After 3h of this video I started to realize how much I already know about wordpress and most importantly that perhaps I can actually make my own website with it. Neverending stream of heart emojis to you guys! Big, big, all caps "THANK YOU" with a lot of exclamation marks!

replies.author: jakub gadzala
replies.text: Very informative! Thank you! After I finish this I will dig into your channel!

replies.author: Dev Drawer
replies.text: @Gigagagagamer Is it an Elementor error  showing "Something went wrong" or is it WordPress? It sounds like something may be typed wrong and WordPress is showing an error. Try this, go to your wp-config.php file and turn on debugging to see if WordPress will show you the error. Any updates to Elementor should not break the theme as it uses standard WP functionality. My guess would be something is wrong with the code that gathers the theme on WordPress's side. let me know if that helps.

topLevelComment.author: Charles Luck
topLevelComment.text: Before I spend 5 hours watching this, riddle me this... is this going to be an interactive database driven website? I enjoy the ease with which one can create a WordPress website, with headers and footers, and the overall theme, but I can't seem to find a coherent and cohesive explanation of how to inject my own code to control the content of each page in a process flow.  Too many videos tend to be hours long sessions of "do this, do this, do that"; without providing any cohesive reasoning for why, and I walk away learning nothing.  Not to mention that I simply cannot bear foreign accents beyond the first two or three sentences. I would rather hear a lecture in Hindi than one by an Indian trying to speak English; and I don't comprehend a word of Hindi. Perhaps it makes no sense to use WordPress for interactive websites, but it would be nice to remove the front-end coding from the equation. Let someone else can the visuals, and let me write the back-end process logic to create the content.

topLevelComment.author: Angelo Leite
topLevelComment.text:
1:41:40 If you are getting the post content looping forever, make sure you got the line "the_post()" inside the while in the "index.php" file. If you miss that the index will be stuck in the while bc of not updating the "have_posts()" repeating the "the_content()" line forever. Make sure index.php and page.php are the same too while you are at it.

Also if post is not displaying in ../practice-area/service-one/ try going to Setting>Permalinks and pressing "Save Changes".

Good tutorial!

replies.author: Shahn Christian Velasco
replies.text: thank you very much for this info

What could be the cause?

replies.author: Magikarp
replies.text: @Angelo Leite Thanks, I probobly made the same mistake but it turns out I need to do more stuff with my theme anyway.

replies.author: Angelo Leite
replies.text: @Magikarp I found out what it was. The index.php was missing the "the_post()" line inside the while. It never updated the "have_posts()" so it would keep repeating "the_content()" forever.

topLevelComment.author: Chris Wood
topLevelComment.text: Unfortunately I watched about 10 minutes of this video before giving up. This site jumps straight into setting up a 'local server' without any explanation of what one is or why you should need it. Not at all helpful to those who are not already fairly knowledgeable , as is my case.

replies.author: Canardeur
replies.text:
You don't need a server for local development purpose since PHP comes with a server included.
Just open a terminal and navigate to the root folder of your project, then type: _php -S localhost:3000_ (or whatever port number you like).
Then, in your browser, enter localhost:3000 as the URL and you are done.

topLevelComment.author: Priya S
topLevelComment.text: I'm having trouble installing wamp. When I try to open it I get an error that there are certain dll libraries not installed: msvcp120 msvcr120. How should I install it?

replies.author: Raymond
replies.text:
during the installation wizard I think on the second page, it requires you to have certain Visual C++ Redistributables that are listed there. On that page there is a link that you can follow to wamp's website to download all the vsredistributable .exe's in one go. That package download is near the bottom of the webpage. 

Just go through the list of all the exe's by running them as Administrator. If you have it, the install wizard will pop up with a Repair or Delete page, so you can close it. If you don't have it, the wizard will have a regular installation page, so go ahead and install it. 


There is also a program you can download from wamp that should be linked on that second install wizard page to tell you if you have vcredists missing.

topLevelComment.author: Lokendra Dutt Joshi
topLevelComment.text:
Thank you FCC and specially DevDrawer . 
 
Please  help me I am getting this error ..... 


Deprecated: Theme without header.php is deprecated since version 3.0.0 with no alternative available. Please include a header.php template in your theme. in C:\xampp\htdocs\wordpress\wp-includes\functions.php on line 4973

replies.author: Dev Drawer
replies.text:
You can add a blank header.php to your theme. I don't use a custom header in the theme so I didn't add one and I did not get an error message.

If you add a blank header and footer to the theme and the error should go away. If you are creating a child theme to use rather than a custom theme, make sure you Template: the-parent-template-name to the comments in your styles.css file.

I hope this helps.

replies.author: Dilmurod Ismoilov
replies.text: @Dev Drawer Thank you for your attention, I think without php codes it will be great.

replies.author: Dev Drawer
replies.text:
One of the benefits of using Elementor is you don't need to know too much PHP. You can create the pages and post types within an Elementor page. I chose to use PHP to create the shortcodes we could pull from the custom post type and custom meta boxes, but you could create all of your pages within Elementor.

It is more about understanding WordPress rather than PHP as the functions I used are standard WordPress functions, we just added code to make it display. I hope that explains it a bit more.

@Dev Drawer thank you so much for your answer. I am trying to move a  project on WordPress and  I am trying to figure out how to make a personal theme from scratch there.
The project is broken in various part like html and css3 footer and header but for the main content we want to use review plug in.
So can we make a custom theme by transferring our header html and css on header.php and footer.php and then personalise that review plug in it's own css files so it can much our header and footer?
What about the overall Layout of the whole website (if we assume that header and footer are made in CSS Grid Layout? Mobile Responsivess etc?
WordPress template system takes care by default the different parts? So no need to have a css that will point on each element of the website in what CSS grid layout area is?

replies.author: Dev Drawer
replies.text: You can add a header.php and footer.php file to your theme folder. You should be able to create a custom header using that file. Elementor allows it to work as a template within Elementor, but it is not required.

topLevelComment.author: SyntacOps
topLevelComment.text: Is it recommended to install all those extras (caching plugin, security, image processing etc.) in the production env or is it ok to install them already in dev stage?

replies.author: SyntacOps
replies.text: @Dev Drawer  Thank you for the response!

replies.author: Dev Drawer
replies.text:
I wouldn't install caching or security on the dev stage. I would also be reluctant about SEO on the dev server. Those plugins are mostly used in conjunction with a live server. You can see from my video, I had issues with the caching because my WAMP server did not have some of the capabilities turned on.

The security plugin rewrites your htaccess file so I would definitely leave that one for your production server.

replies.author: Dev Drawer
replies.text: Elementor and the CMB + CPT generators can be great tools to work with but don't use them as a crutch. Learn how to create your own theme without them. I use them for fast projects but with large projects, I use custom code because it is easier to maintain and control. Learn this way for simple projects but also expand your knowledge and learn more about WP core and you will find out you can create some really creative projects on your own.

topLevelComment.author: Lemon Squeezer
topLevelComment.text:
I don't want to sound like a jackass, because someone has put 5 hours into making this tutorial and put it up for free. But after skipping through the timestamps, i noticed there are a lot of mistakes in this tutorial and the finished product is a mess of plugins that are all over the place. So many plugins for such a simple website is really overkill and makes the whole project look unprofessional and messy. Most, if not all of this could have been done purely by coding it yourself and it would be much cleaner and not much harder to do, also the project size wouldn't be anywhere near 90+MB that the current one is thanks to all the plugins and what not.
The title should also be changed to something that includes Elementor, because there is more Elementor in this tutorial than actual PHP. Its not a tutorial for people who want to learn how to code or improve their PHP, because almost everything is made with 3rd party plugins in this video.
Honestly I would just recommend using Wix or Squarespace at this point rather than doing this...

Anyway, my intention is not to offend anyone, because presenter is noticably nervous during this video, so i hope he also learns something from this tutorial aswell and looking forward to seeing him improve and present again.

replies.author: Dev Drawer
replies.text: @Sam Anderson Hey, thanks for replying. To each their own.

replies.author: Sam Anderson
replies.text:
@Dev Drawer In your word: "Learn how to build a completely custom website..." Elementor is everything but custom. It's a website configurator with an option to hack something together with some code. It's a bit more nuanced than you seem to think.

In your word again: "I thought Elementor would be an easier way for under-experienced developers to get started." 

Under-experienced developers should learn HTML/CSS inside out, NOT how to use Elementor and hack some code. Tutorials like this are very popular and common. It is why the web is where it is today. 

I see you just want people to blow smoke up your behind on YouTube for more likes to stroke your ego. I don't have to like what's wrong. There is indeed such a thing called right and wrong, or good practice and bad practice. Just saying. Good luck with your endeavor.

replies.author: Dev Drawer
replies.text:
@Sam Anderson I don't understand how this video is convoluted and not easy for beginners. The only difficult part of this project for a beginner to understand would maybe be the part where I create the single post type pages, just because I used the free version of Elementor for the video and you can't create a single page type with the free version. Otherwise, the tutorial shows how to setup a local WAMP server, install WordPress, create the design, install the plugins required to recreate exactly what I did, and use them effectively. 

Everything I used is free for them to install and try out. On top of that, they don't even need to create the shortcodes or the custom post types...they can just use Elmentor to create the pages. I understand the hate for Elementor or other GUI-based editors for WordPress from an experienced developer, but obviously, if you can create a theme from scratch, you don't need Elementor. I create it from scratch all the time but I thought Elementor would be an easier way for under-experienced developers to get started.

Just FYI, I built the client site that I based this project off of using custom code, but I thought showcasing Elementor for people who may not be able to build the site from scratch would give them a sense of some of the capabilities of something like Elementor + WordPress. I have plenty of tutorials on my channel detailing how to build a Wordpress theme without Elementor, I even have a series for it. 

Just because it is not something you like, doesn't mean that other people would dislike it. From the comments and thumbs up, a lot of people appreciate the video. I don't disagree with all of your points but I think you are thinking about this tutorial coming from a background of experience. This video does not show my typical workflow, but I think that some people will appreciate it...even if it is not something I use daily. 

Just like with WordPress or PHP or C# or Java or Node or Angular...you either like it or you don't. There are always people that say their way is better but to the individual users, it is all about what helps them the most. If this tutorial doesn't help you, then let it help someone else.

replies.author: Sam Anderson
replies.text: @Mico I agree, and you aren't being mean by pointing out the flaws. Those of us who know HTML/CSS/PHP/JS/WordPress theme development would not build a WordPress website this way. It's one of the most convoluted ways to build a WordPress site I've ever seen. It is not easy for beginners, and it is not great for developers, either. What's the point of this methodology then? People just can't help buying into the illusion that non-savvy clients would somehow figure out how to use Elementor and update the website with it. They won't, and I've dealt with hundreds of them by now. They build crap with it and then cry. Some garbage plugin like Elementor would make a WordPress website heavier and heavier as you put more content on the site.

replies.author: Dev Drawer
replies.text:
@Lemon Squeezer Ah, I get it. I also think I say "so" a lot. I have been working on that, but it is hard. I think it is just the way I talk when I am recording because I do it live, so I am thinking about what I am doing, what I need to do next, and how the video is recording. A lot is going on at the same time and causes my brain to lag a bit at times. :) 

As for the typos, we all have typos...not because I am nervous but just really bad at spelling or my fingers don't work as fast as my brain sometimes. I leave them in because if I create an issue with a mistyped word, I want them to see how to fix it. In my other videos, there are parts where I completely blow something up, but I leave it in because I want people to know what to do if they run into the same issue I did. I think the videos are more organic if they are not edited to be perfect, but to show imperfection.

replies.author: Dev Drawer
replies.text: You can use anything. I use illustrator, but you can do it with wireframes. I fast-forwarded through the design part because it was not super important for this video since you can use anything or nothing. Take a look at the code because you can create this website without or without illustrator, so you can still celebrate. :)

replies.author: freeCodeCamp.org
replies.text: You don't need to know Illustrator. You can skips that section if you like and still follow along.

topLevelComment.author: Bondy Magnomous
topLevelComment.text: Hello, again, thank you for another amazing video. However, is PHP still being used for website development though?

replies.author: A9 Arnav
replies.text: @Bondy Magnomous  It's  good to know your point on this. But node js is current trend in web development. Also its easy to develop and maintain by a team of coders.

replies.author: Bondy Magnomous
replies.text: @Tensaiz Ok but if you were to develop a new website, would you use PHP? It's just I keep hearing it's a deprecated language for web development.

replies.author: Tensaiz
replies.text: @A9 Arnav depends, a lot of website hosts only support PHP by default, which means it can be a quick way to set up a small website with a few backend functionalities (e.g: email sender) and this also means a lot of newer websites also use PHP. Just think about all those new wordpress websites made by non-developers relying on plugins.

replies.author: A9 Arnav
replies.text: @Tensaiz But it is for old websites maintenance

replies.author: Tensaiz
replies.text: Roughly 80% of the web uses PHP for a backend, so it's good to understand it

topLevelComment.author: Chris Rotunno
topLevelComment.text: What an awful stack

replies.author: rand0m
replies.text: @Dev Drawer Agree, great tutorial btw

replies.author: Dev Drawer
replies.text:
@rand0m I can agree with you if you don't expand your knowledge. I started with PHP way back in the day, used WordPress for a time but didn't limit what I know to just that. Now, I develop using PHP, Python, Ruby, C#, and .NET. I use each on a daily basis, but for quick sites or small clients, WordPress is ideal because it is easy for them to learn and use. 

If you rely on plugins heavily then you will never get outside of WordPress. Usually, I build everything custom, but this tutorial is more geared towards new developers that may not be able to do this without a bit of help from plugins. This tutorial may not be for experienced developers or devs in other stacks but it may help a lot of developers with an interest in WP development.

replies.author: rand0m
replies.text: Worst stack for sure, you get stuck in that ecosystem and only know plugins,wp and php, nothing else than that. Not so much room for further improvements.

replies.author: Tensaiz
replies.text: Exactly, it might not be ideal, but is a good idea to at least get some knowledge in case you encounter it (which you probably will)

replies.author: freeCodeCamp.org
replies.text: It is one of the most popular stacks on the internet. :)
